lg.l: Everyone who is committed to going step-by-step
along the completely correct Way of Lord Nr̥patuṅga.
will unfailingly be able to attain a rank that comes from
toiling on poetry of unsurpassable beauty by means of this system.
Through the learnedness that comes from
serving the Young Woman who is Śruti
one who has understood without any gaps
the opinions and recommendations regarding ornaments
proclaimed by King Atiśayadhavaḷa,
will become the best among those who have fulfilled their duty.

note.p: This verse contains three words that are used elsewhere in the Way as titles of King Nr̥patuṅga: Atiśayadhavaḷa, Nītinirantara, and Kr̥takr̥tyamalla. If, however, we try to read them as titles in the present verse, we cannot produce a coherent meaning. The repetition of the titles, then, is only an “apparent repetition” (punaruktyābhāsa). We follow Seetharamaiah’s lead in reading two of these words in their literal senses, such that the verse as a whole functions as a phalaśruti, which speaks of the benefits of studying the Way. One such benefit is that the reader actually takes on the qualities that are embodied in Nr̥patuṅga’s titles.

lg.l: In the beauty of local speech, expression
is not allowed to exceed the idea
as if intending to conform to it.
The state of Sanskrit expressions serves as the standard
for Kannada speech without getting tangled up
in its intimidating syllables.
In this way, the system of Nītinirantara is put forth,
expansive and delicate, like a long creeping vine left to grow.

note.p: We take melpu in the sense of “delicateness,” although B uncharacteristically writes a long vowel (mēlpu), which suggests that the word ought to be derived from mēl “above” (thus “superiority”) rather than mel “delicate.” This word, in our reading, suggests a contrast between the “beauty” (beḍaṅgu) of local speech and the “intimidating” (vikaṭa-) syllables of Sanskrit.
We also understand the word padaṁ to have a double meaning: as a dēśī word, it refers to the proper or mature state of something; as a samasaṁskṛta word, it refers to a word or expression.
For the phrase dāṅguḍiviḍuva, see Pampa, Bhārata 2.12.

lg.l: By manifesting different configurations of syllables, like a painter manifests
different combinations of colors, which sparkle with beauty and emotion,
poets enter into the storied divide between the realm of discourse
and the totality of the arts. In order to produce a work of art in speech,
poets must take this in hand: this method produced by Śrīvijaya.

note.p: This verse thematizes the close relationship of verbal and pictoral art, using the ornaments of a simile (“like a painter”) and, secondarily, “condensed expression” or samāsōkti: the word varṇa means “color” in the context of painting, and “syllable” in the context of poetry.

lg.l: The qualities that beautify the body
of the supreme and excellent bride who is the work
are defined as unsurpassable ornaments,
well-known to the ancient poets.

note.p: This verse is an adaptation of the initial verse of the second chapter of Daṇḍin’s Mirror of Literature, which defines alaṁkāras or “ornaments” as “those qualities which impart beauty to a literary work” (kāvyaśōbhākarān dharmān alaṁkārān pracakṣatē).

lg.l: In the assessment of the Ways
according to the analytical system
of the Beloved and Splendid Nr̥patuṅga,
the classification of the supreme ornaments,
which can appear in a wide variety of forms,
is twofold, according to the division into sound and sense.
Moreover, to describe it in my own way,
the ornaments of sound should be considered first among these two.
Since they form the basis of the meaning,
they are more important and unique.
